name: Vatnajökull National Park
description: Vatnajökull National Park is Iceland's largest national park and one of Europe's largest protected wilderness areas, encompassing approximately 14,967 square kilometers (about 14% of Iceland's land area). Established in 2008 through the merger of Jökulsárgljúfur and Skaftafell national parks with the Vatnajökull glacier region, the park protects an extraordinary diversity of landscapes including Europe's largest glacier, active volcanic systems, powerful waterfalls, glacial rivers, black sand deserts, and unique ecosystems. The park extends from the highlands of the Vatnajökull ice cap down to the southern coast, encompassing some of Iceland's most iconic natural attractions including Jökulsárlón glacier lagoon, Skaftafell wilderness area, Dettifoss waterfall, and Ásbyrgi canyon. The park represents the full spectrum of Icelandic natural phenomena, from ice to fire. Beneath the Vatnajökull glacier lie several active volcanic systems including Bárðarbunga, Grímsvötn, and Öræfajökull, creating unique interactions between glacial and volcanic forces. The park has witnessed some of Iceland's most powerful natural events including the 2014-2015 Holuhraun eruption, glacial floods (jökulhlaups), and ongoing glacial retreat driven by climate change. The area supports diverse flora and fauna including Arctic fox, reindeer (in parts of the east), numerous bird species, and unique adaptations to extreme conditions. The park was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2019.
